According to the Americans these groups are funded, trained, and armed by the Iranian [[Quds Force]], part of the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]]. According to American General Kevin J. Bergner, the Special Groups receive between 750,000 and 3,000,000 dollars funding per month from the Quds Force.{{cite web|url=http://www.usf-iraq.com/?option=com_content&task=view&id=12653&Itemid=128|title=The Official Website - United States Forces – Iraq|publisher=|accessdate=7 November 2014}} These groups are separate from but allied with the [[Mahdi Army]] of [[Muqtada al-Sadr]]. The distinction between these groups and the Mahdi Army became more clear when al-Sadr called for a ceasefire at the end of August 2007 following Mahdi Army [[Battle of Karbala (2007)|clashes]] with [[Iraqi Security Forces]] in [[Karbala, Iraq|Karbala]] but the Special Groups continued fighting. After the Mahdi Army's disbandment in 2008, the [[Promised Day Brigades]] emerged as its successor; however, the largest special group to emerge after the [[Iraq spring fighting of 2008]] was [[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]] (also known as the Qazali Network). According to the Guardian newspaper in March 2014, Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq is controlled by Iran under Quds Force General [[Qasem Soleimani]].[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/12/iraq-battle-dead-valley-peace-syria Controlled by Iran, the deadly militia recruiting Iraq's men to die in Syria], The Guardian, 12 March 2014 Another large special group is [[Kata'ib Hezbollah]] (or Hezbollah Brigades) which started to operate independently from the Mahdi Army and the other Special Groups. Suspected leaders include [[Qais al-Khazali]], [[Laith al-Khazali]], [[Ali al-Lami]], [[Azhar al Dulaimi]], [[Akram al-Kabi]], [[Abu Mustafa al-Sheibani]], [[Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis]] and [[Abu Deraa]]. ==History== Ever since the [[1979 Iranian revolution|Islamic Revolution]], Iran has sought to back Shia Islamist paramilitary organizations across the Middle East. Many have been very close to the Iranian state, particularly the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]], like the Movement of Vanguard Missionaries and the [[Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq]] (SCIRI). During the [[Iran–Iraq War]] many of these groups fought for Iran, with SCIRI's [[Badr Organization|Badr Brigade]] being led by Iranian officers. After the US overthrow of Saddam Hussein, these Iranian-led militia men returned to Iraq where they retained their autonomy and Iran continued to support Shia Islamist paramilitaries. In February 2010, Asaib Ahl al-Haq kidnapped U.S. contractor Issa T. Salomi, a naturalized American from Iraq. They released a video of him where he read their demands, calling for the release of all the group's members, including several of the group's leaders who are currently imprisoned.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=118051§ionid=351020201 |accessdate=April 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120531064657/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=118051§ionid=351020201 |archivedate=May 31, 2012 }} Iran is supporting three Shiite extremist groups in Iraq that have been attempting to attack American bases, General Ray Odierno, the top U.S. commander in Iraq, said on July 21, 2010. The Iranians have "gone to a more sophisticated program with a smaller set of extremists" and are now focusing on three groups, which he identified as Kataib Hezbollah, Asaib Ahl al-Haq (League of the Righteous), and the Promised Day Brigade.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jCA6iGhsEI3i-z4hAG8Z2Cu4kV3Q] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724040950/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jCA6iGhsEI3i-z4hAG8Z2Cu4kV3Q |date=July 24, 2010 }} As of 2011, according to American officials, the Promised Day Brigades is the largest, with over 5,000 fighters, and pose the biggest long-term security threat to Iraq. Kata'ib Hezbollah is said to have around 1,000 fighters and is the most exclusively reliant on Iranian support. Asa'ib al-Haq is said to have less than 1,000 fighters as of 2011 and receives a reported 5 million per month in Iranian funding. The Promised Day Brigades is said to receive the least amount of Iranian funding and is the most independent of the three. Since the beginning of the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–present)|Iraqi war against ISIS]], the Special Groups have joined the [[Popular Mobilization Forces (Iraq)|Popular Mobilization Forces]] to fight against the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]. ==Leaders== {| class="wikitable" style="border:1px solid #8888aa; background:#f8f8f8; padding:0; font-size:90%;" |- !Name !Group !Rank !Status |- ||[[Muqtada al-Sadr]]||[[Promised Day Brigade]]||Spiritual Leader||In Iran,{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/14/AR2007021400450.html?nav=hcmodule|title=Armed Iraqis Wary of Security Plan|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=7 November 2014}} since 2006. Returned to Iraq in January 2011.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011151418794320.html|title=Al-Sadr back in Iraq stronghold|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=7 November 2014}} |- |[[Qais al-Khazali]]||[[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]]||Leader||Captured on March 20, 2007 in Basra,{{cite web|url=http://www.usf-iraq.com/?option=com_content&task=view&id=12641&Itemid=131|title=Press Briefing, July 2 |publisher=|accessdate=7 November 2014}} released on January 5, 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2010/jan/05/iraq-frees-militant-linked-to-british-hostages/|title=Iraq frees militant linked to British hostages|work=U-T San Diego|accessdate=7 November 2014}} |- |[[Laith al-Khazali]]||[[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]]||Deputy Leader||Captured on March 20, 2007 in Basra, released June 9, 2009{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/09/shia-militant-iraq-british-hostages|title=US frees Shia militant linked to British hostages in Iraq|author=Martin Chulov|work=the Guardian|accessdate=7 November 2014}} |- |[[Akram al-Kabi]]||[[Asa'ib Ahl al-Haq]]||Acting leader||At large |- |[[Abu Mustafa al-Sheibani]]||[[Sheibani Network]]||Leader||In [[Tehran]], Iran, since 2008,[[United States Department of the Treasury]] [http://www.ustreas.gov/press/releases/hp759.htm Treasury Designates Individuals, Entity Fueling Iraqi Insurgency] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528030129/http://www.ustreas.gov/press/releases/hp759.htm |date=2010-05-28 }} returned to Iraq in September 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2010/09/30/Iraq-Return-of-Sheibanis-killer-squads/UPI-36301285859253/|title=Iraq: Return of Sheibani's killer squads|work=UPI|accessdate=7 November 2014}} |- |[[Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis]]||[[Kata'ib Hezbollah]]

[[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1700 and on.gif|500px|thumb|Political evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1700 to present]] This is a timeline of the '''territorial evolution of the Caribbean''' and nearby areas of [[North America|North]], [[Central America|Central]], and [[South America]], listing each change to the internal and external borders of the various countries that make up the region. The region covered is the Caribbean, its islands (most of which enclose the sea), and the surrounding coasts, as well as the southern part of the [[Gulf of Mexico]], [[Florida]], [[Central America]], and the northern region of South America. The political evolution of the land surrounding the Caribbean reveals the significant role the region played in the colonial struggles of the European powers since [[Christopher Columbus]] arrived in 1492. In the 20th century the Caribbean was again important during World War II, in the [[decolonization]] wave in the post-war period, and in the tension between [[Communist]] [[Cuba]] and the United States (U.S.). Genocide, slavery, immigration and rivalry between world powers have given Caribbean history an impact disproportionate to the size of this small region. At the time of the [[European colonization of the Americas|European]] discovery of most of the islands of the Caribbean, three major [[Amerindian]] [[indigenous peoples]] lived on the islands: the [[Taíno people|Taíno]] in the [[Greater Antilles]], [[Bahamas|The Bahamas]] and the Leeward Islands; the [[Island Caribs]] and [[Galibi]] in the [[Windward Islands]]; and the [[Ciboney]] in western [[Cuba]]. The Taínos are subdivided into Classic Taínos, who occupied Hispaniola and Puerto Rico, Western Taínos, who occupied Cuba, Jamaica, and the Bahamian archipelago, and the Eastern Taínos, who occupied the Leeward Islands.{{cite book | last = Irving Rouse| title = The Tainos: Rise and Decline of the People Who Greeted Columbus|edition= July 28, 1993|pages= 224 | publisher = Yale University Press| isbn= 0-300-05696-6}} [[Trinidad]] was inhabited by both [[Carib language|Carib speaking]] and [[Arawak language|Arawak-speaking]] groups. ==1700== [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1700 na.png|right|250px]] In 1700 Spain ruled what is now North America, Central America, South America and the major islands of the Caribbean. Other players were the: ;Kingdom of England who controlled: *[[Mosquito Coast]] - The Mosquito Coast or eastern portion of what is now [[Nicaragua]] was declared to be under the protection of the English crown in 1687.{{cite web |quote=Data as of December 1993|url = http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/nitoc.html|title = Colonial Rule|publisher = Library of Congress Call Number F1523 .N569 1994| accessdate = 2009-05-07 | last=[[USA.gov]] }}''In 1687 the English governor of Jamaica named a Miskito who was one of his prisoners, "King of the Mosquitia Nation", and declared the region to be under the protection of the English crown.'' *[[Anguilla]] - In 1650, English settlers arrived from [[St Kitts]] and colonized Anguilla. In 1656 Indians from a neighboring island came and destroyed the settlement. The French temporarily overtook the island in 1666 but under the [[Treaty of Breda (1667)|Treaty of Breda]] it was returned to English control.{{cite web |year=2009 |url = http://www.anguilla-vacation.com/island/history-culture|title = History & Culture|publisher = anguilla-vacation.com| accessdate = 2009-05-07 | last=Adapted from the works of Colville Petty O.B.E and Nik Douglas. |quote=}} *[[Antigua and Barbuda]] - As part of the Treaty of Breda France formally ends its claim of Antigua in 1667 giving control to the British. In 1685 the plantation owner [[Christopher Codrington]], a sugar planter from Barbados leases the island of Barbuda from the British crown.{{cite web |date=9 April 2009|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/country_profiles/1202625.stm|title = Timeline: Antigua and Barbuda|publisher = [[BBC News]]| accessdate = 2009-05-07 |quote=}} *[[Bahamas]] - In 1670 [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] granted the islands to the [[William Craven, 1st Earl of Craven (1608–1697)|Earl of Craven]] a [[Lord Proprietor]] of the Carolinas, who rented the islands from the king with rights of trading, tax, appointing [[Governor#British Empire and Commonwealth of Nations|governor]]s, and administering the country.{{cite web |year=2009 |url = http://bahamas.anglican.org/history.php|title = Diocesan History|publisher = © Copyright 2009 Anglican Communications Department| accessdate = 2009-05-07 |quote=}} *[[Barbados]] - British sailors who landed on Barbados in 1625 arrived at the site of present-day [[Holetown]]. From the arrival of the first British settlers in 1627–1628 until independence in 1966, Barbados was under uninterrupted British control.{{cite web|year=2009 |url=http://www.barbados.gov.bb/history.htm |title=Archeological |publisher=Government of Barbados |accessdate=2009-05-07 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426110953/http://barbados.gov.bb/history.htm |archivedate=2009-04-26 |df= }} *[[Belize|British Honduras (Belize)]]" English [[buccaneer]]s began cutting logwood (''[[Haematoxylum campechianum]]''), which was used in the production of a textile [[dye]]. English buccaneers began using the coastline as a base from which to attack Spanish ships. Buccaneers stopped plundering Spanish logwood ships and started cutting their own wood in the 1650s and 1660s. Logwood extraction then became the main reason for the English settlement for more than a century. A 1667 treaty, in which the European powers agreed to suppress piracy, encouraged the shift from buccaneering to cutting logwood and led to more permanent settlement.Bolland, Nigel. "Belize: Historical Setting". In [http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/bztoc.html ''A Country Study: Belize''] (Tim Merrill, editor). [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (January 1992). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].'' *[[British Virgin Islands]] - During the 1698 negotiations between the Netherlands and the British over the ownership of the islands an order from the King become known. The King in 1694 issued an order to prevent foreign settlement in the Virgin Islands. In February 1698 Governor [[Christopher Codrington]] was told to regard the earlier 1694 orders as final, and the British entertained no further claims to the islands.{{cite book | last = Isaac Dookhan| title = History of the Virgin Islands|edition= August 2000|pages= 336 | publisher = University Press of the West Indies| isbn= 976-8125-05-5}} *[[Cayman Islands]] - The islands were captured, then ceded to England in 1670 under the [[Treaty of Madrid (1670)|Treaty of Madrid]].{{cite web|year = 2009|url = http://www.cayman.gov.ky/servlet/page?_pageid=560&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&_mode=3|title = History|publisher = The government of the Cayman Islands|accessdate = 2009-05-07|quote = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060427100313/http://www.cayman.gov.ky/servlet/page?_pageid=560&_dad=portal30&_schema=PORTAL30&_mode=3|archivedate = 2006-04-27|df = }} *[[Jamaica]] - Jamaica was captured, then ceded to England in 1670 under the [[Treaty of Madrid (1670)|Treaty of Madrid]] *[[Montserrat]] - Fell under English control in 1632.{{cite web |date=23 April 2009|url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mh.html|title = Montserrat|publisher = [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]]| accessdate = 2009-05-07 |quote=}} *[[Saint Kitts and Nevis]] - After the [[Kalinago Genocide of 1626]], [[Saint Kitts]] was partitioned between the British and French, with the French gaining the ends, Capisterre in the North and Basseterre in the south, and the British gaining the centre. In 1689, during the War of the Grand Alliance, France re-occupied the entire island, and decimated the British farms. English retaliation by General Codrington defeated the French forces and deported them to Martinique. The Treaty of Rijswijk in 1697 restored pre-war conditions. [[Nevis]] was ruled by the British *[[Saint Lucia]] - In 1664, Thomas Warner (son of the governor of St Kitts) claimed Saint Lucia for England. He brought 1,000 men there to defend it from the French, but after two years there were only 89 left, mostly due to disease. *[[Turks and Caicos Islands]] - Bermudians claimed the islands for Britain and came to Turks & Caicos to rake the salt and take it back to Bermuda. Salt was a precious commodity back then as it was used not only for flavoring food but for preserving it as well. The official name of the country at the time was the Republic of Colombia.{{cite encyclopedia |title=Gran Colombia |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica Online |date=6 June 2007 |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9037644}} Historians adopted the term "Gran Colombia" to distinguish this republic from the present-day Republic of Colombia, which began using the same name in 1863.p 12. - {{cite book|last=Bushnell|first=David|title=The Santander Regime in Gran Colombia|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Connecticut|year=1970|isbn=0-8371-2981-8|oclc=258393}} [[File:Adams onis map.png|200px|thumb|left|Map showing results of the Adams-Onís Treaty.]] *The '''[[Adams–Onís Treaty]]''' of 1819,formally titled the '''Treaty of Amity, Settlement, and Limits Between the United States of America and His Catholic Majesty''', sometimes the '''Florida Purchase Treaty''' also known as the '''Transcontinental Treaty of 1819''', settled a border dispute in North America between the United States and Spain. The treaty was the result of increasing tensions between the U.S. and Spain regarding territorial rights at a time of weakened Spanish power in the [[New World]]. In addition to ceding [[Florida]] to the United States, the treaty settled a boundary dispute along the [[Sabine River (Texas–Louisiana)|Sabine River]] in [[Texas]] and firmly established the boundary of U.S. territory and claims through the [[Rocky Mountains]] and west to the Pacific Ocean in exchange for the U.S. paying residents' claims against the Spanish government up to a total of $5,000,000 and relinquishing its own claims on parts of Texas west of the Sabine River and other Spanish areas under the terms of the [[Louisiana Purchase]].{{cite web |year=2009 |url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ho/time/jd/16320.htm |title = Acquisition of Florida: Treaty of Adams-Onis (1819) and Transcontinental Treaty (1821)|publisher = [[USA.gov]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | last=[[USA.gov]] |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1821 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1821 na.png|right|250px]] *On November 9, 1821 the Spanish colony of [[Colony of Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo]] was toppled by a group led by Spanish General [[José Núñez de Cáceres]].{{cite web | last = Lancer | first = Jalisco | title = The Conflict Between Haiti and the Dominican Republic | work = | publisher = All Empires Online History Community | url = http://www.allempires.com/article/index.php?q=conflict_haiti_dominican | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2007-12-24 }}{{cite web |title=Haiti - Historical Flags |work=Flags of the World |url=http://www.flag.de/FOTW/flags/ht-hist.html#span |accessdate=2007-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050505041710/http://www.flag.de/FOTW/flags/ht-hist.html |archivedate=2005-05-05 |df= }} Forces which opposed unification with Haiti formally declared independence from Spain on November 30, 1821.{{cite book | last = Gates | first = Henry Louis |author2=Appiah, Anthony | title = Dominican-Haitian Relations | work = Africana: The Encyclopedia of the African and African American Experience | year = 1999 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xE-N8hh-VNQC&pg=PA617&lpg=PA617&dq=spanish+haiti&source=web&ots=K8EfPYcsI4&sig=iMgEI31tSdkdtfcURxRZKAaYyh0#PPA617,M1 | accessdate = 2007-12-24 }} The new nation was known as '''República del Haití Español''' (Republic of Spanish Haiti). *The [[Mexican War of Independence]] lasted eleven years until the troops of the liberating army entered [[Mexico City]] in 1821. Thus, although independence from Spain was first proclaimed in 1810, it was not achieved until 1821, by the [[Treaty of Córdoba]], which was signed on August 24 in Córdoba, Veracruz, by the Spanish viceroy [[Juan O'Donojú]] and Agustín de Iturbide, ratifying the [[Plan of Iguala]].{{cite web |year=2009 |url = https://www.pbs.org/kpbs/theborder/history/interactive-timeline.html|title = Mexican Timeline|publisher = [[Public Broadcasting Service]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1822 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1822 na.png|right|250px]] [[Dominican Republic|Spanish Haiti]]'s independence was short-lived, as Haitian forces, led by [[Jean Pierre Boyer]], invaded and took control of the country just nine weeks later in February 1822.{{cite web |year=2007 |url = http://www.haiti-usa.org/haiti_basics/|title = Haiti Basics |publisher = haiti-usa.org| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1823 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1823 na.png|right|250px]] After a brief time as part of the [[First Mexican Empire|Mexican Empire]] of [[Agustín de Iturbide]] *[[Guatemala]] (which initially included a large part of what is now the Mexican state of Chiapas), *[[El Salvador]] *[[Honduras]] *[[Nicaragua]] *[[Costa Rica]] became a state in the [[Federal Republic of Central America]] on July 1, 1823.{{cite web |year=2007 |url = http://latinamericanhistory.about.com/od/historyofcentralamerica/a/09republicofCA.htm|title = The Federal Republic of Central America (1823–1840)|publisher = [[About.com]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | last=Christopher Minster |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1830 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1830 na.png|right|250px]] *In 1830, [[José Antonio Páez]] declared Venezuela independent from Gran Colombia and became president. Although he was not the first president of Venezuela (which declared its independence from Spain in 1811 and had at the moment [[Cristóbal Mendoza]] as head of its [[Executive (government)|executive]] [[triumvirate]]) Páez was the first head of government after the dissolution of Gran Colombia.{{cite book |author1=H. Michael Tarver |author2=Hollis Michael Tarver Denova |author3=Julia C. Frederick | title = The history of Venezuela|edition= October 30, 2005|pages= 216 | publisher = Greenwood Press| isbn= 0-313-33525-7}} *Throughout the 1820s Ecuador was the center of much fighting. First, the country found itself on the front lines of Gran Colombia's efforts to liberate Peru from Spanish rule between 1822 and 1825; afterward, in 1828 and 1829, Ecuador was in the middle of an armed [[Gran Colombia–Peru War|struggle between Peru and Gran Colombia]] over the location of their common border. The Treaty of 1829 fixed the border on the line that had divided the Quito audiencia and the [[Viceroyalty of Peru]] before independence. In May 1830 a group of Quito notables met to dissolve the union with Gran Colombia, and in August, a constituent assembly drew up a constitution for the State of Ecuador, so named for its geographic proximity to the equator, and placed [[Juan José Flores|General Juan José Flores]] in charge of political and military affairs. He remained the dominant political figure during Ecuador's first fifteen years of independence.{{cite web|year = 2009|url = http://encarta.msn.com/text_761565312___35/Ecuador.html|title = Ecuador VI. In the 1830s Rafael Carrera was an illiterate but shrewd and charismatic [[swineherd]]er turned [[highwayman]] but by 1838 Carrera became de facto ruler of much of Guatemala. The Carrera revolt inspired other Conservatives to revolt against the [[Federal Republic of Central America]], and soon [[Federal Republic of Central America]] was at civil war. Carrera was instrumental in leading the revolt against the Federal government and breaking it apart. File:Boundary lines of British Guiana 1896.jpg| *A map of the borders of the British colony Guyana was published in 1840. 2nd edition| isbn= 1-55876-191-8}} [[Ramón Matías Mella]] and [[Francisco del Rosario Sánchez]] (the latter of partly African ancestry),{{cite web |url=http://www.27febrero.com/duarte.htm |title=juan pablo duarte |accessdate=2009-05-01 |last=Barros |first=Ramón |work=Historia Patria Dominicana |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428094329/http://www.27febrero.com/duarte.htm |archivedate=2009-04-28 |df= }} despite not being among the founding members of La Trinitaria, were decisive in the fight for independence. They were backed by [[Pedro Santana]], a wealthy cattle rancher from [[El Seibo]], who became general of the army of the nascent Republic. The Dominican Republic's first Constitution was adopted on November 6, 1844, and was modeled after the [[United States Constitution]].{{cite web|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761563569_7/Dominican_Republic.html#s31 |title=Dominican Republic |accessdate=2007-06-06 |work=Encarta Encyclopedia |publisher=Microsoft Corporation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114170306/http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761563569_7/Dominican_Republic.html |archivedate=2007-11-14 |df= }} {{Clear}} ;1846 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1846 na.png|right|250px]] [[Yucatán (state)|Yucatán]] renounced the [[:en:Mexico|Mexican]] government, declaring independence effective 1 January 1846. The two men negotiated the terms of sale for the building of a [[Panama Canal]]. the UK on November 30, 1966 .{{cite web |year=2009 |url = http://www.barbados.org/history1.htm|title = Barbados Culture: THE ABBREVIATED HISTORY OF BARBADOS|publisher = barbados.org| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} *[[Guyana]] achieved independence on May 26, 1966 from the UK, and became the Co-operative Republic of Guyana on February 23, 1970 - the anniversary of the Cuffy slave rebellion - with a new constitution.{{cite web |date=March 2009|url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/1984.htm|title = Background Note: Guyana|publisher = [[USA.gov]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} http://www.caricom.org/jsp/community/anguilla.jsp?menu=community|title = ANGUILLA|publisher = Caribbean Community|accessdate = 2009-05-01|quote = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090521120649/http://www.caricom.org/jsp/community/anguilla.jsp?menu=community|archive-date = 2009-05-21|dead-url = yes|df = }} {{Clear}} ;1973 [[File:Political Evolution |date=July 9, 1973|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/9/newsid_2498000/2498835.stm|title = 1973: Bahamas' sun sets on British Empire|publisher = [[BBC News]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1974 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1974 na.png|right|250px]] On February 7, 1974 [[Grenada]] gains independence from the UK.{{cite web |date=August 25, 1997|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-sir-eric-gairy-1247273.html|title = Obituary: Sir Eric Gairy |work=[[The Independent]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | last=Hugh O'Shaughnessy |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1978 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1978 na.png|right|250px]] On November 3, 1978 [[Dominica]] became an independent |publisher = dominicacompanies| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | last=N. E. Leigh. Clerk of the Privy Council. |quote=}} {{Clear}} ;1979 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1979 na.png|right|250px]] *[[Saint Lucia]] became independent from the United Kingdom on February 22, 1979.{{cite web|year = 2009|url = http://www.itzcaribbean.com/stluciahistory|title = CARIBBEAN HISTORY|publisher = © itzcaribbean.com Caribbean London|accessdate = 2009-05-01|quote = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090312051104/http://www.itzcaribbean.com/stluciahistory|archive-date = 2009-03-12|dead-url = yes|df = }} *[[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] became independent from the United Kingdom October 27, 1979 .{{cite web |date=March 2009|url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2345.htm|title = Background Note: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|publisher = [[USA.gov]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} *The existence of the [[Panama Canal Zone]], a political exclave of the U.S. that cut [[Panama]] geographically in half and had its own courts, police and civil government, was a cause of conflict between the USA and Panama. Demonstrations occurred at the opening of the [[Bridge of the Americas]] in 1962 and serious rioting occurred in 1964.{{cite web |date=March 31, 1982|url = http://www.serve.com/CZBrats/Articles/czp.htm|title = A HISTORY OF THE CANAL ZONE POLICE|publisher = Presented by CZBrats| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | last=William F. Kessler |quote=}} This led to the United States easing its controls in the Zone. For example, Panamanian flags were allowed to be flown with American ones. After extensive negotiations the Canal Zone ceased to exist on October 1, 1979 in compliance with provisions of the [[Torrijos–Carter Treaties]].{{cite web|date=December 1999 |url=http://www.usembassy-mexico.gov/bbf/bfdossier_PanamaCanal.htm |title=TRANSFER OF THE PANAMA CANAL |publisher=American Embassy in Mexico |accessdate=2009-05-01 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118044547/http://www.usembassy-mexico.gov/bbf/bfdossier_PanamaCanal.htm |archivedate=January 18, 2009 }} {{Clear}} ;1981 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1981 na.png|right|250px]] *[[Antigua and Barbuda]] became an independent state from the United Kingdom on November 1, 1981.{{cite web |year=2009 |url = http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Antigua_and_Barbuda.html|title = Antigua and Barbuda|publisher = worldstatesmen.org| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} *The constitution of 1964 established internal self-rule but Guatemalan claim to sovereignty over the territory of Belize delayed full independence until September 21, 1981. Throughout Belize's history, [[Guatemala]] has claimed ownership of all or part of the territory. This claim is occasionally reflected in [[map]]s showing Belize as Guatemala's twenty-third [[Departments of Guatemala|department]]. As of March 2007, the border dispute with Guatemala remains unresolved and quite contentious;{{cite web |date=26 March 2000|url = http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/47/185.html|title = ACP-EU supports Belize's sovereignty|publisher = Amandala Online| accessdate = 2009-05-08 |quote=}} at various times the issue has required mediation by the United Kingdom, [[Caribbean Community]] heads of Government, the [[Organisation of American States]], Mexico, and the United States. Since independence, a British garrison has been retained in Belize at the request of the Belizean government. {{Clear}} ;1983 [[File:Political Evolution of Central America and the Caribbean 1983 na.png|right|250px]] On September 19, 1983 [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]] became an independent nation from the United Kingdom.{{cite web |date=March 2009|url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2341.htm|title = Background Note: Saint Kitts and Nevis|publisher = [[USA.gov]]| accessdate = 2009-05-01 |quote=}} {{Clear}} ==See also== *[[Territorial evolution of the British Empire]] ==Notes== *In the following images not all islands are to scale with some being changed to be easier to see. *After 1902, Cuba is shown as an independent nation, although the [[Platt Amendment]] gave the United States the final word on Cuban affairs.{{cite web |year=2009 |url = https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ho/time/ip/86557.htm|title = The United States, Cuba, and the Platt Amendment, 1901|publisher = [[USA.gov]]| accessdate = 2009-05-03 |quote=}} *Not shown is: **[[Navassa Island]] is a small, uninhabited island in the Caribbean Sea, and is an unorganized unincorporated territory of the United States, which administers it through the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The island is thought to have been claimed by Haiti prior to being claimed by the United States, as far back as 1801. **The island of [[Tobago]] changed hands at least 22 times altogether between the French, Dutch, British and [[Courland colonization of the Americas|Courlanders]] (the Duchy of [[Courland]], at that time a fief of Poland was located in what is now modern western and southern [[Latvia]]) and was controlled at times by various pirate groups. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Caribbean topics}} {{Territorial evolution of the world}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Territorial Evolution Of The Caribbean}} [[Category:Territorial evolution|Caribbean]] [[Category:History of Central America]] [[Category:History of the Caribbean]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{about|the French far-right conspiracy theory|the article about the broader concept|White genocide conspiracy theory}} {{Expand French|Grand remplacement|date=September 2018}} {{Islamophobia}}'''The great replacement''' ({{lang-fr|le grand remplacement}}) is a far-right conspiracy theory,<ref>{{unordered list|{{cite journal |last1=Froio |first1=Caterina |title=Race, Religion, or Culture? Framing Islam between Racism and Neo-Racism in the Online Network of the French Far Right |journal=Perspectives on Politics |date=21 August 2018 |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=696–709 |doi=10.1017/S1537592718001573 |quote=...the conspiracy theory of the Grand remplacement (Great replacement) positing the 'Islamo-substitution' of biologically autochthonous populations in the French metropolitan territory, by Muslim minorities mostly coming from sub-Saharan Africa and the Maghreb}}|{{cite journal |last1=Sowerwine |first1=Charles |title=The Far Right in a Neo-Liberal Age: Pessimism, Sexism and Racism in Modern French Thought |series=Perspectives on Politics |journal=French History & Civilization |year=2017 |volume=7 |pages=190–203 |accessdate=24 September 2018 |quote=...the Grand Remplacement (Great Replacement), a lunar right - or is the term now "alt right?" - conspiracy theory about a plot to effect "the progressive replacement, over a few decades, of the historic population of our country by immigrants, the vast majority of them non-European. |url=https://h-france.net/rude/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/vol7_Sowerwine.pdf}}|{{cite book |first1=Edwy |last1=Plenel |author-link=Edwy Plenel |title=For the Muslims: Islamophobia in France |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=crjrCgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher=Verso Books |date=28 June 2016 |isbn=978-1-78478-488-1 |via=Google Books}}| {{cite news |last1=Serhan |first1=Yasmeen |title=Pivotal Elections Loom Over Europe |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/liveblogs/2017/05/europe-elections/513677/ |accessdate=24 September 2018 |work=The Atlantic |quote=...the 'great replacement' conspiracy theory that contends immigrants are replacing the traditional French population.}}}}</ref><ref name="Sowerwine 2018">{{cite book |last=Sowerwine |first=Charles |title=France since 1870 : Culture, Politics and Society |publisher=Palgrave |location=London |year=2018 |isbn=978-1-137-40611-8 |oclc=1051356006 |page=460 |quote=Zemmour flirted with a far-right conspiracy theory; the Grand remplacement (Great Replacement)}}</ref><ref name="Deutsche Welle">{{cite news |title=How dangerous are Austria's far-right hipsters? {{!}} DW {{!}} 28 August 2018 |url=https://www.dw.com/en/how-dangerous-are-austrias-far-right-hipsters/a-45241401 |accessdate=24 September 2018 |work=''DW.COM'' |quote=...and spread the 'great replacement' conspiracy theory – the idea that white Europeans will be replaced by people from the Middle East and Africa through immigration. The theory is based on inflated statistics and un-substantiated demographic projections. Right now, only 4 percent of the European Union is made up of non-EU nationals.}}</ref><ref name="Baldauf 2017">{{cite book |last=Baldauf |first=Johannes |title=Toxische Narrative : Monitoring rechts-alternativer Akteure |publisher=Amadeu Antonio Stiftung |location=Berlin |year=2017 |isbn=978-3-940878-29-8 |oclc=1042949000 |language=nl |page=11 |quote=...this narrative is highly compatible with concrete conspiracy narratives about how this replacement is desired and planned, either by 'the politicians' or 'the elite,' which-ever connotes Jewishness more effectively. |url=https://www.amadeu-antonio-stiftung.de/w/files/englisch/monitoring-2017-englisch-int.pdf}}</ref><ref name="La Croix">{{cite web |url=https://www.la-croix.com/France/Exclusion/VIDEO-campagne-deconstruire-discours-complotistes-Internet-2018-01-26-1200909107 |title=A campaign to deconstruct conspiracy discourse on the Internet |date=26 January 2018 |work=[[La Croix]] |quote=...le " grand remplacement ", une théorie de type conspirationniste selon laquelle il existerait un processus de remplacement des Français sur leur sol par des non-Européens.}}</ref> which states that the white Catholic French population, and white Christian European population at large,<ref name="Eurozine">{{cite news |title=The philosophical sources of Marine Le Pen |url=https://www.eurozine.com/the-philosophical-sources-of-marine-le-pen/ |publisher=[[Eurozine]] |date=12 October 2017 |quote=...a conspiracy theory which claims that the global elite has staged a plot to replace the indigenous European population with immigrants from other continents}}</ref> is being systematically replaced with non-European people,<ref name="La Croix" /> specifically Middle Eastern, North and Sub-Saharan African populations,<ref name="Deutsche Welle" /> through mass migration and demographic growth. It associates the presence of Muslims in France with potential danger and destruction of French culture and civilization.<ref name="Le Pen advisor">{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/marine-le-pen-adviser-robert-menard-guilty-muslim-islam-hatred-latest-a7701721.html |title=Marine Le Pen adviser found guilty of inciting hatred against Muslims |date=25 April 2017 |work=[[The Independent]]}}</ref>
The conspiracy theory commonly apportions blame to a global and liberal elite,<ref name="Eurozine" /> such as [[Brussels and the European Union]], which is portrayed as directing a planned and deliberate plot or scheme to carry out the replacement of European peoples.<ref name="Baldauf 2017" />
The theory has been popularized by [[Renaud Camus]]. This notion of replacement, or of [[White genocide conspiracy theory|white genocide]], has echoed throughout the rhetoric of many anti-migrant far-right movements in the West.<ref name="Bergmann 2018 p.">{{cite book |last=Bergmann |first=Eirikur |title=Conspiracy & Populism : The Politics of Misinformation |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |location=Cham, Switzerland |year=2018 |isbn=978-3-319-90359-0 |oclc=1049171816 |page=127}}</ref> Among its main promoters are not only far-right populist parties but also a wide-ranging network of protest movements (e.g., [[Pegida]]), ideological groupuscules (e.g., [[bloc identitaire]]),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/generation-identity-far-right-group-training-camps-europe-uk-recruits-military-white-nationalist-a8046641.html |title=Generation Identity: Far-right group sending UK recruits to military-style training camps in Europe |date=9 November 2017 |work=[[The Independent]] |quote=...claims it represents "indigenous Europeans" and propagates the far-right conspiracy theory that white people are becoming a minority in what it calls the "Great Replacement"}}</ref> bloggers (e.g., [[Fjordman]]), and noted intellectuals (e.g., [[Eric Zemmour]]). Prominent radical right-wing websites such as [[Gates of Vienna]], [[Politically Incorrect (blog)|Politically Incorrect]], and [[France de Souche]] have provided a platform for bloggers to diffuse and popularize the conspiracy theory.<ref name="Betz">{{cite book |last=Betz |first=Hans-Georg |editor-last=Rydgren |editor-first=Jens |title=Oxford Handbooks Online |volume=1 |chapter=The Radical Right and Populism |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=5 February 2018 |doi=10.1093/oxfordhb/9780190274559.013.5 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--5IDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT121#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=|isbn=9780190644185 }}</ref>
==Origins== The theory of the great replacement can be traced back to the 1973 novel ''[[Le Camp des Saints]]'' by [[Jean Raspail]] which depicts the collapse of Western culture owing to an overwhelming "tidal wave" of Third World immigration. The novel, along with the theory of [[Eurabia]] developed by the Swiss-Israeli writer [[Bat Ye'or]] in 2005, set the ground then for [[Renaud Camus]] to develop and present his book entitled ''The Great Replacement'' in 2012.<ref name="Abdeslam">{{cite journal |last1=Ait Abdeslam |first1=Abderrahim |title=The vilification of Muslim diaspora in French fictional novels: 'Soumission' (2015) and 'Petit Frère' (2008) as case studies |journal=Journal of Multicultural Discourses |volume=13 |issue=3 |date=28 August 2018 |pages=1–11 |doi=10.1080/17447143.2018.1511717}}</ref> Credited as the "progenitor of the Great Replacement doctrine" by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center|SPLC]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2018/07/05/hate-europe-june-2018 |title=Hate in Europe: June 2018 |work=Hatewatch |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}</ref> Camus has stated that "the great replacement is very simple. You have one people, and in the space of a generation you have a different people".<ref>{{cite news |title=The French Origins of 'You Will Not Replace Us' |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/12/04/the-french-origins-of-you-will-not-replace-us |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=4 December 2017}}</ref> Camus has argued that [[European culture]], civilization and identity are in danger of being overrun by mass migration, especially Islamic, and hence physically replaced.<ref>{{cite news |title="You will not replace us": a French philosopher explains the Charlottesville chant |url=https://www.vox.com/world/2017/8/15/16141456/renaud-camus-the-great-replacement-you-will-not-replace-us-charlottesville-white |date=15 August 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[White genocide conspiracy theory]] * [[Counter-jihad]] * [[Eurabia]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} '''Torna atrás''' ({{IPA-es|toɾnaˈtɾas}}) or '''Tornatrás''' is a term once used in [[Spain]] and its former [[Spanish colonial empire|overseas colonies]] to describe a mixed race person ([[mestizaje|mestizo]]) that showed [[phenotypic]] characteristics of only one of the "original races",<ref name="RAE">{{cite web | url=http://dle.rae.es/?id=a64p6qK| title=Definición de tornatrás | publisher=Real Academia Española | accessdate=21 September 2016}}</ref> that is, white, black, Amerindian or Asian. The term was also used to describe an individual whose parentage was half white and half "[[octoroon|albino]]".<ref name="RAE"/>
[[File:IX. From Spaniard and Albino, Return Backwards (De espanol y albina, torna atras) LACMA M.2011.20.2 (5 of 5).jpg|thumbnail|[[Casta#Casta paintings in 18th-century Mexico|Casta painting]] of a Spanish father, albino mother and torna atrás child. [[Juan Patricio Morlete Ruiz]] (Mexico, circa 1760)]] ==Colonial Spanish America== Under the [[casta]] system of colonial [[Spanish America]], the torna atrás (in English, similar in meaning to throwback, hark back to) could also make reference to the appearance of racial characteristics not present in the parents. Such as in the [[colored]] child of a white person and albino. The albino casta refers to the seemingly white offspring of a white and black-descended parent (afromestizo).
==Philippines== It was also used in the [[Philippines]] during the [[History of the Philippines (1521-1898)|Spanish colonial era]] from the 16th to 19th century, to describe persons of mixed indigenous [[Austronesian peoples|Austronesian]] (referred to as ''[[Spanish East Indies|Indio]]''), [[Sangley|Chinese]] (referred to as ''Sangley''), and [[Peninsulares|Spanish]] ancestry (referred to as ''Filipinos''/''Insulares'' or ''Peninsulares'').
It is likely that a majority of [[Filipino people]] today would have been classified as ''Tornatrás'' under this system due to centuries of intermarriage among various foreign and indigenous ethnic groups throughout the islands.
==History== Although Tornatrás was originally used to describe a descendant of [[mestizos]], albinos and Europeans, in the Philippines they were commonly known as those born from a Spanish father ('Filipino' or 'peninsular') and a Malay-Chinese (mestiza de [[sangley]]) mother.
Most people of the Tornatrás caste in the Philippines used [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as their primary language and in many cases converted to the Catholic faith.
There are no official statistics on the number of people of Tornatrás ancestry around the world, although it is believed that most are to be found in South America and the Philippines.
==See also== *[[Sandra Laing]] *[[Miscegenation]] *[[Mulato]] *[[Filipino mestizo]] *[[Eurasian (mixed ancestry)|Eurasian]]

'''Whole of Government Accounts''' ('''WGA''') is the annual publication by the [[United Kingdom]] [[UK Government|Government]] of the Consolidated [[financial statement]]s of over 5,500 organisations across the public sector.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/whole-of-government-accounts |title=Whole of Government Accounts |publisher=[[HM Treasury]] |accessdate=15 May 2016}} It aims to provide more complete data for fiscal planning by producing consolidated financial statements which are produced in accordance with the [[International Financial Reporting Standards]] (IFRS), the system of accounts used internationally by the private sector. The accounts are [[Auditor independence|independently audited]] by the [[Comptroller and Auditor General]]{{cite web |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/wga_200910_guidance.pdf |title=Guidance to the Whole of Government Accounts y/e 31/03/10 (''vid.'' p.4) |publisher=[[HM Treasury]] |accessdate=27 January 2011}} and get scrutinized by the [[Public Accounts Committee]] each year. ==Background== The Treasury first published a scoping study for WGA in July 1998. The first set of accounts to be published will be for the [[Fiscal year|year ended]] 31 March 2010. WGA are prepared under Sections [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/20/crossheading/whole-of-government-accounts 9 to 11] of the Government Resources and Accounts Act 2000. WGA are prepared for the whole of the UK [[public sector]] ([[Government of the United Kingdom|central government]], [[Local government in the United Kingdom|local government]], [[National Health Service|health]], and [[Government-owned corporation|public corporations]]). WGA are prepared under [[International Financial Reporting Standards]].{{cite web |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/wga_200910_guidance.pdf |title=Guidance to the Whole of Government Accounts y/e 31/03/10 (''vid.'' p.21) |publisher=[[HM Treasury]] |accessdate=27 January 2011}} ==Structure== The Structure of the document is the same as you'd get for any private sector organisation using [[IFRS]]. In particular the following consolidated statements are included: *Consolidated [[Income statement|Statement of Revenue and Expenditure]] with the [[other comprehensive income]] part shown as a seporate statement; *Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income *consolidated [[Balance sheet|Statement of Financial Position]], showing public sector assets and liabilities; *Consolidated [[Statement of changes in equity|Statement of Changes in Taxpayers’ Equity]] *consolidated [[Cash flow statement|Cash Flow Statement]]; and *[[Notes to the financial statements|Notes to the Accounts]] It also includes a Statement on Internal Control as well as detailing the [[Accounting Officer]]’s responsibilities and a [[Remuneration Report]] ==Results for FY 2010== The Whole of Governments Accounts for the year ended 31 March 2010 was published on 29 November 2011. It was the first ever set of audited financial statements for the UK public sector. The 2009-10 WGA brings together, for the first time, audited financial information from the UK’s central government, local government, the National Health Service (NHS) and public corporations. It makes clear a number of metrics that previously had been difficult to calculate, such as the net public service pension liability, the Government’s commitments under [[private finance initiative]] (PFI) contracts, total provisions, and contingent liabilities. As this is the first year in which WGA is published, there is no historical data for comparison. Over time, annual publications of WGA will allow the user to build up a clear and consistent picture of trends and changes in the Government’s fiscal position. WGA also allows for international comparisons of fiscal balance sheets to be made, provided that other countries’ accounts are produced on a comparable basis. The accounts are available on the UK's Treasury website: http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/wga. ==Audit Report== The Whole of Government Accounts are subject to audit by the [[Comptroller and Auditor General (United Kingdom)|Comptroller & Auditor General]] (C&AG). The C&AG audited the 2009-10 WGA and concluded:
"In my opinion, except for the effects of the matters described in the Basis for Qualified Opinion paragraphs above:
*
the financial statements give a true and fair view of the state of the affairs of the Whole of Government as at 31 March 2010 and of its net deficit, changes in taxpayers’ equity and cash flows for the year then ended; and
*
the financial statements have been properly prepared in accordance with the Government Resources and Accounts Act 2000.”
The C&AG report on the 2009-10 WGA is [http://www.nao.org.uk/publications/1012/wga_2009-10.aspx available on the National Audit Office's website]. ==See also== * [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]] (UK) * [[Gold reserves of the United Kingdom]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/psr_government_accounts.htm HM Treasury -
